description.narrative: Stöd för organisations- och kapacitetsutveckling av ECOMUN och lokala kooperativ för avmobiliserade FARC-medlemmar, genom den svenska civilsamhällesorganisationen We Effect. Insatsen ämnar bidra till genomförandet av fredsavtalet mellan Colombias regering och FARC och på så sätt till en hållbar fred med mänsklig säkerhet, genom att förbättra förutsättningarna för före detta gerillasoldaters socio-ekonomiska återintegrering i samhället, med fokus på socialt och miljömässigt hållbar produktiv sysselsättning och jämställdhetsintegrering. ECOMUN är den organisation som FARC föreslagit i syfte att stödja och stärka de lokala kooperativ som deras ex-kombattanter bildar. Projektet har utvecklats tillsammans med ECOMUN och We Effect tillhandahåller resurser och specialiserad rådgivning för bildandet av organisationen, samt dess möjligheter att fungera och utvecklas till en ledande organisation för den kollektiva återintegreringsprocessen, i linje med ex-kombattanternas egna behov och önskemål. Ingen vidareförmedling av medel sker till ECOMUN eller de lokala kooperativen.

Support for organizational and capacity development of ECOMUN and local cooperatives for demobilized FARC members, through the Swedish civil society organization We Effect. The effort aims to contribute to the implementation of the peace agreement between the Government of Colombia and the FARC and thus to a lasting peace with human security, by improving the conditions for the socio-economic reintegration of former guerrilla soldiers into society, focusing on socially and environmentally sustainable productive activities and gender integration. ECOMUN is the organization proposed by the FARC in order to support and strengthen the local cooperatives formed by their ex-combatants. The project has been developed together with ECOMUN and We Effect provides resources and specialized advice for the formation of the organization, as well as its possibilities to operate and develop into a leading organization for the collective reintegration process, in line with the ex-combatants' own needs and wishes. No transfer of funds takes place to ECOMUN or the local cooperatives.

The overall objective of the intervention is to contribute to peacebuilding in Colombia through the reintegration of FARC ex-combatants and their full exercise of citizenship and related rights in conditions of equality. The intervention will contribute specifically to the establishment and development of ECOMUN, the cooperative organisation of ex-FARC combatants, as a vehicle for transformation and for the creation of conditions and mechanisms for effective reincorporation of ex-combatant men and women within the framework of a social, solidarity and environmentally sustainable economy. Expected results by the end of the intervention are: Result 1: ECOMUN is strengthened as a democratic cooperative organisation under the principles of the solidarity economy for the effective participation of ex-combatant women and men and the communities surrounding the reincorporation areas, within the framework of the peace agreement’s implementation. Result 2: ECOMUN’s grassroots, ex-combatant women and men and the communities surrounding the reincorporation areas have identified concrete initiatives for community reincorporation and collaboration in social and economic life at the local level.

title.narrative: Decision on contribution 12204- Reincorporation Colombia We Effect
Decision on major amendment-12204- Reincorporation Colombia We Effect

description.narrative: The pandemic and restrictions put in place to halt the spread of the virus seriously affected project implementation during 2020. Ecomun and the local cooperatives had to cancel or re-schedule most of their activities, including the ones that the project supports, thus halting project implementation for the better part of the year. Although some activities were carried out despite the difficulties, the expected results were not achieved during the period and the contribution has been extended until September 2021 – to allow Ecomun and the local cooperatives to make up for the time lost to the pandemic and continue progress towards the results, with the support of We Effect. Significant progress has been made since implementation of the contribution began, including the formal constitution of Ecomun and several local cooperatives, as democratic cooperative organisations under the principles of the solidarity economy, as well as the launch of several initiatives for community reincorporation and collaboration in social and economic life at the local level. However, developments in the context exacerbated by the pandemic have also required adjustments to the project and to Sida’s contribution. The initial assumption for the intervention was that the peace agreement would be implemented at a rapid pace, in a general context of stability and security. It was also assumed that Ecomun would establish itself quickly and be able to support its members in accessing rights and services, and that the government of Colombia would swiftly provide full support to the process, as stipulated in the peace agreement. However, the peace talks with the ELN-guerrilla failed in early 2019 and the security situation has deteriorated in many regions of the country, particularly for FARC ex-combatants. The implementation of the agreement is also progressing slower and with greater difficulty than expected, translating into slower progress in reintegration, including with regards to land rights and rural reform - that are important to many collective reintegration initiatives. Legal and regulatory requirements have also posed a more serious than expected obstacle to the organizational and productive efforts of ECOMUN. The impression is that there was trust in the good faith of the previous government to “make things work”, whereas the current government emphasizes strict compliance with applicable regulations, under its "peace with legality" policy. All these factors are external, beyond the control of the project, but they make the reintegration-process slower and more demanding. In a sense, the contribution is therefore less likely to produce the expected results and - even if they are achieved - the results are less likely to have the foreseen impact on the overall outcome of the reintegration-process within the time-frame of the contribution. Due to these difficulties, support to the reintegration-process has never been more important. Sida concludes that the contribution is still highly relevant but recognizes that the efforts supported will need to be sustained over time to produce the desired changes. It is also important that the reintegration-process is supported in such a way that it contributes to building and strengthening local capacities for peace, that will increase the longer term chances for successful peacebuilding - even if the current reintegration process or even the larger peace-process was to falter and not produce the immediate benefits that everyone expected and hoped for when the peace agreement was signed in 2016.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
